comment_message_cleaned: ROUNDUP is killing us---------EXCERPT FROM------SURGICAL NEUROLOGY INTERNATIONAL---------------------The number of sports-related concussions has been steadily rising in recent years. Diminished brain resilience syndrome is a term coined by the lead author to describe a particular physiological state of nutrient functional deficiency and disrupted homeostatic mechanisms leading to increased susceptibility to previously considered innocuous concussion. We discuss how modern day environmental toxicant eure, along with major changes in our food supply and lifestyle practices, profoundly reduce the bioavailability of neuro-critical nutrients such that the normal processes of homeostatic balance and resilience are no longer functional. Their diminished capacity triggers physiological and biochemical ‘work around’ processes that result in undesirable downstream consequences. Eure to certain environmental chemicals, particularly glyphosate, the active ingredient in the herbicide, Roundup®, may disrupt the body's innate switching mechanism, which normally turns off the immune response to brain injury once danger has been removed. Deficiencies in serotonin, due to disruption of the shikimate pathway, may lead to impaired melatonin supply, which reduces the resiliency of the brain through reduced antioxidant capacity and alterations in the cerebrospinal fluid, reducing critical protective buffering mechanisms in impact trauma. Depletion of certain rare minerals, overuse of sunscreen and/or overprotection from sun eure, as well as overindulgence in heavily processed, nutrient deficient foods, further compromise the brain's resilience. Modifications to lifestyle practices, if widely implemented, could significantly reduce this trend of neurological damage. Reference Wendy A. Morley (Thionetic Nutrition) and Dr. Stephanie Seneff

text_original:
ROUNDUP is killing us---------EXCERPT FROM------SURGICAL NEUROLOGY INTERNATIONAL---------------------The number of sports-related concussions has been steadily rising in recent years. Diminished brain resilience syndrome is a term coined by the lead author to describe a particular physiological state of nutrient functional deficiency and disrupted homeostatic mechanisms leading to increased susceptibility to previously considered innocuous concussion. We discuss how modern day environmental toxicant exposure, along with major changes in our food supply and lifestyle practices, profoundly reduce the bioavailability of neuro-critical nutrients such that the normal processes of homeostatic balance and resilience are no longer functional. Their diminished capacity triggers physiological and biochemical ‘work around’ processes that result in undesirable downstream consequences. Exposure to certain environmental chemicals, particularly glyphosate, the active ingredient in the herbicide, Roundup®, may disrupt the body's innate switching mechanism, which normally turns off the immune response to brain injury once danger has been removed. Deficiencies in serotonin, due to disruption of the shikimate pathway, may lead to impaired melatonin supply, which reduces the resiliency of the brain through reduced antioxidant capacity and alterations in the cerebrospinal fluid, reducing critical protective buffering mechanisms in impact trauma. Depletion of certain rare minerals, overuse of sunscreen and/or overprotection from sun exposure, as well as overindulgence in heavily processed, nutrient deficient foods, further compromise the brain's resilience. Modifications to lifestyle practices, if widely implemented, could significantly reduce this trend of neurological damage.
Reference Wendy A. Morley (Thionetic Nutrition) and Dr. Stephanie Seneff

comment_message_cleaned: FROM WHITEWASH BY CAREY GILLAM...Monsanto's Roundup is killing us...................Another prime example of hidden alliances has come to be known as the “Séralini affair.” Gilles-Eric Séralini was a professor of molecular biology at the University of Caen Normandy when he published a study in September in a scientific journal called Food and Chemical Toxicology (FCT) about the effects of Roundup herbicide and Roundup Ready corn on rats. Publication in a journal such as FCT requires a lengthy process in which eerts unrelated to the study review it and can ask questions and seek revisions before it is published. This peer review process is meant to curb publication of flawed research. Séralini had spent two years and more than $3 million working with seven other scientists to study how the genetically modified corn and the herbicide impacted the animals’ health. At the time, Séralini was also president of a scientific advisory board that worked with a group opposed to GMOs. He believed there were potential problems with GMOs and Roundup that had not yet been uncovered by the scientific research that was largely funded by the chemical industry. Séralini and his team had seen troubling results in previous studies, including evidence that Roundup herbicides containing POEA along with glyphosate were much more harmful than glyphosate alone, causing cell damage at levels eected to be found in food.5 Groups of rats were evaluated by the Séralini team in the study. The rats were divided into males and females. Some were fed genetically engineered corn; others consumed corn sprayed in the field with Roundup; and others were given Roundup in drinking water in different doses, with the lowest corresponding to levels found in some tap water. The intermediate dose was set at the maximum level permitted in the United States in animal feed, and the highest dose was correlated to half the strength of Roundup as used in agriculture. Control group rats were fed a diet containing non–genetically engineered corn and plain drinking water. The Séralini study results were alarming. Treated rats had much higher death rates than the control group animals, and the eed rats demonstrated an “uneected increase in tumor incidence,” especially mammary tumors in female rats, along with damage to the animals’ livers and kidneys. The scientists said both the GMO corn and Roundup contributed to the health problems that developed in the eerimental animals, and they said they found “uneected low dose toxicity from Roundup” at levels ,000 times lower than those permitted in drinking water in the United States.6 The study results “clearly indicate that lower levels of complete agricultural G [glyphosate] herbicide formulations, at concentrations well below officially set safety limits, can induce severe hormone-dependent mammary, hepatic, and kidney disturbances,” the study authors concluded.7 Séralini said his research gave credence to fears that Roundup contains ingredients more toxic than glyphosate and that Roundup formulations should be considered endocrine disruptors. Gillam, Carey. Whitewash: The Story of a Weed Killer, Cancer, and the Corruption of Science (p. ). Island Press. Kindle Edition.

text_original:
FROM WHITEWASH BY CAREY GILLAM...Monsanto's Roundup is killing us...................Another prime example of hidden alliances has come to be known as the “Séralini affair.” Gilles-Eric Séralini was a professor of molecular biology at the University of Caen Normandy when he published a study in September 2012 in a scientific journal called Food and Chemical Toxicology (FCT) about the effects of Roundup herbicide and Roundup Ready corn on 200 rats. Publication in a journal such as FCT requires a lengthy process in which experts unrelated to the study review it and can ask questions and seek revisions before it is published. This peer review process is meant to curb publication of flawed research. Séralini had spent two years and more than $3 million working with seven other scientists to study how the genetically modified corn and the herbicide impacted the animals’ health. At the time, Séralini was also president of a scientific advisory board that worked with a group opposed to GMOs. He believed there were potential problems with GMOs and Roundup that had not yet been uncovered by the scientific research that was largely funded by the chemical industry. Séralini and his team had seen troubling results in previous studies, including evidence that Roundup herbicides containing POEA along with glyphosate were much more harmful than glyphosate alone, causing cell damage at levels expected to be found in food.5 Groups of rats were evaluated by the Séralini team in the 2012 study. The rats were divided into males and females. Some were fed genetically engineered corn; others consumed corn sprayed in the field with Roundup; and others were given Roundup in drinking water in different doses, with the lowest corresponding to levels found in some tap water. The intermediate dose was set at the maximum level permitted in the United States in animal feed, and the highest dose was correlated to half the strength of Roundup as used in agriculture. Control group rats were fed a diet containing non–genetically engineered corn and plain drinking water. The Séralini study results were alarming. Treated rats had much higher death rates than the control group animals, and the exposed rats demonstrated an “unexpected increase in tumor incidence,” especially mammary tumors in female rats, along with damage to the animals’ livers and kidneys. The scientists said both the GMO corn and Roundup contributed to the health problems that developed in the experimental animals, and they said they found “unexpected low dose toxicity from Roundup” at levels 10,000 times lower than those permitted in drinking water in the United States.6 The study results “clearly indicate that lower levels of complete agricultural G [glyphosate] herbicide formulations, at concentrations well below officially set safety limits, can induce severe hormone-dependent mammary, hepatic, and kidney disturbances,” the study authors concluded.7 Séralini said his research gave credence to fears that Roundup contains ingredients more toxic than glyphosate and that Roundup formulations should be considered endocrine disruptors.
Gillam, Carey. Whitewash: The Story of a Weed Killer, Cancer, and the Corruption of Science (p. 117). Island Press. Kindle Edition.

comment_message_cleaned: Climate has never been stagnant. It's the natural world after all. Always changing. But the rate at which the climate is changing, is the concern. We have witnessed atmospheric changes (Co2 and temperate etc., levels rise) within the last years, that in all previous climate change processes, took thousands. Pretty simple to grasp that one! And while flaura and fauna have the capacity to adapt, they do not have the capacity to adapt that quickly. Therefore, we risk the loss of many. In addition, millions of human humans are threatened by other impacts... Sea level rise in low elevation cities, drought and water shortages, not just in arid places but widespread accross all continents. Those are just a few among many other detrimental threats.

comment_message_cleaned: Ecologists believe beavers can make Canada wet again. Here is an idea to help prevent future fires and reforest burned out areas. ... / This link shows a process that has been researched by scientists. This has also been successfully done in Canada, and back in the ’s by the state of Idaho. They succeeded in saving state park acreages by relocating beavers. Idaho already built a carrier that floats gently to the ground and opens, after being dropped from an airplane. This process will work in Canada if done on a large scale, say -2000 beavers to start with. These containers can be dropped by airplane and made out of biodegradable materials so they wouldn't need to be picked up. Within the past years Canada tried this process, they were able to forest, what had previously been grasslands, within -7 years. If nothing is done, Canada will look like Mexico within years, and the surrounding states will follow. The state of WA recently tried this with beavers. The first winter after they did this - , all of the water reservoirs in California were refilled. Since water rises straight up, this program would turn Canada into a large humidifier. Canada and all the western states should try this to keep the desert at bay. Please feel free to share this.

text_stemmed: [u'ecologist', u'believ', u'beaver', u'make', u'canada', u'wet', u'idea', u'help', u'prevent', u'futur', u'fire', u'reforest', u'burn', u'area', u'link', u'show', u'process', u'research', u'scientist', u'also', u'success', u'done', u'canada', u'back', u'state', u'idaho', u'succeed', u'save', u'state', u'park', u'acreag', u'reloc', u'beaver', u'idaho', u'alreadi', u'built', u'carrier', u'float', u'gentl', u'ground', u'open', u'drop', u'airplan', u'process', u'work', u'canada', u'done', u'larg', u'scale', u'say', u'2000', u'beaver', u'start', u'contain', u'drop', u'airplan', u'made', u'biodegrad', u'materi', u'need', u'pick', u'within', u'past', u'year', u'canada', u'tri', u'process', u'abl', u'forest', u'previous', u'grassland', u'within', u'year', u'noth', u'done', u'canada', u'look', u'like', u'mexico', u'within', u'year', u'surround', u'state', u'follow', u'state', 'wa', u'recent', u'tri', u'beaver', u'first', u'winter', u'water', u'reservoir', u'california', u'refil', u'sinc', u'water', u'rise', u'straight', u'program', u'would', u'turn', u'canada', u'larg', u'humidifi', u'canada', u'western', u'state', u'tri', u'keep', u'desert', u'bay', u'pleas', u'feel', u'free', u'share']
text_original:
Ecologists believe beavers can make Canada wet again. Here is an   idea to help prevent future fires and reforest burned out areas. http://cottagelife.com/.../ecologists-believe-beavers-can  ... / This link shows a process that has been researched by scientists. This has also been successfully done in Canada, and back in the 1940’s by the state of Idaho. They succeeded in saving state park acreages by relocating 75 beavers. Idaho already built a carrier that floats gently to the ground and opens, after being dropped from an airplane. This process will work in Canada if done on a large scale, say 1000-2000 beavers to start with. These containers can be dropped by airplane and made out of biodegradable materials so they wouldn't need to be picked up. 
Within the past 10 years Canada tried this process, they were able to forest, what had previously been grasslands, within 5-7 years. If nothing is done, Canada will look like Mexico within 25 years, and the surrounding states will follow. The state of WA recently tried this with 300 beavers. The first winter after they did this 2016 - 2017, all of the water reservoirs in California were refilled. Since water rises straight up, this program would turn Canada into a large humidifier. Canada and all the western states should try this to keep the desert at bay. Please feel free to share this.

comment_message_cleaned: Paul Gregory I'm working on it. I was able to get through to one Governor, although I reached out to seven. I'm pretty low on the food chain, but if his office hears from the public, maybe he'll listen. In the mean time, I wonder if I could enlist you to forward & share my message with as many people as you can. Especially any environmental groups or people in Government, who would like to see a reversal of the quantity of wildfires and scorched earth. text_original:
Here is an idea to help prevent future fires and reforest burned out areas. http://cottagelife.com/news/ecologists-believe-beavers-can-make-california-wet-again  / This link shows a process that has been researched by scientists. This has also been successfully done in Canada, and back in the 1940’s by the state of Idaho. They succeeded in saving state park acreages by relocating 75 beavers. Idaho already built a carrier that floats gently to the ground and opens, after being dropped from an airplane. This process will work in California if done on a large scale, say 1000-2000 beavers to start with. These containers can be dropped by airplane and made out of biodegradable materials so they wouldn't need to be picked up. 
Within the past 10 years Canada tried this process, they were able to forest, what had previously been grasslands, within 5-7 years. We could import the animals from Canada. I have sent this article to most CA County firefighter departments. If nothing is done, California will look like Mexico within 10 years, and the surrounding states will follow. PS- I also came across an article that stated the state of WA recently tried this with 300 beavers. The first winter after they 2016 - 2017, all of the holding reservoirs in California were refilled. Since water rises straight up, this program would turn the state of California into a humidifier. All the western states and Canada could save their beautiful forests.

The Aral Sea dried up because of water management policies initiated by the Soviet Union. They dammed the hell out of tributaries and feeders and turned it into a source for irrigation.

Saying climate change did that is dishonest.

comment_message_cleaned: Getting sick of this line: "... cannot be ruled out but is unlikely." Source: Infectious disease section of the N.A. right whale necropsy report: UNLIKELY??? To you but NOT TO ME (and others): Dr. Mona Nemer says: "Science is not about beliefs and opinions. Science is about facts. Please be engaged, continue asking questions, participate as much as you can. It will all make us stronger." Well, here's a question based on facts: why isn't anyone looking into what Wolbachia-infected Aedes releases are doing to our food chain and specifically vertebrates? Are we going to foolishly cling to Hertig's results on mice and chicken embryos? Or, are we going to acknowledge and devote resources to testing vertebrates (including humans) for the presence of Wolbachia? Because here are facts that are being willfully ignored: The direct effect of Wolbachia can either impede or promote the pathogen's replication and survival (Zug and Hammerstein, ). Examples of neutral or pro-pathogenic effect of Wolbachia include: Brugia pahangi (Dutton and Sinkins, ); Japanese encephalitis (JE) Virus (Tsai et al., ); Drosophila C Virus (Osborne et al., ); and Plasmodium gallinaceum (Baton et al., ). Wolbachia Enhances West Nile Virus (WNV) Infection in the Mosquito Culex tarsalis: Zika Virus in Salivary Glands of Five Different Species of Wild-Caught Mosquitoes from Mexico: 1 Re: Sexual Transmission of Zika There is commonly held belief that Zika is rarely a sexually-transmitted disease. However, "up to percent of ZIKV cases in Barranquilla, with percent confidence, may have been due to sexual contact alone." Source: 0 North Atlantic right whales are highly promiscuous (as are some humans). Over ,000 cases of Zika were reported in Puerto Rico as of Oct. th, . The waters surrounding many islands in the Caribbean are obviously teeming with Zika-infected Aedes and Culex mosquitoes, eggs, and larvae. Eventually, Cal fin and krill will be nibbling away at them. So, the major food source of North Atlantic right whales will also be eed to the Zika virus and Wolbachia — both are maternally inherited. There are multiple ways these whales could be infected with Wolbachia and/or Zika. Bottom line: These whales (and many marine mammals, shorebirds, and humans) are being eed to inordinate amounts of Wolbachia (a reproductive parasite). When I asked Dr. Daoust about Zika, WNV, SLEV, and Wolbachia, he replied weakly that these whales were in various states of decomposition, downplayed the likelihood of a mosquito biting them and so these were not even considered; nor tested for.

text_original:
Getting sick of this line: "... cannot be ruled out but is unlikely." Source: Infectious disease section of the N.A. right whale necropsy report: http://www.cwhc-rcsf.ca/right_whales.php

UNLIKELY??? To you but NOT TO ME (and 598 others): https://www.change.org/p/investigate-north-atlantic-right-whale-deaths-without-the-noaa-a-u-s-gov-t-agency

Dr. Mona Nemer says: "Science is not about beliefs and opinions. Science is about facts. Please be engaged, continue asking questions, participate as much as you can. It will all make us stronger."

Well, here's a question based on facts: why isn't anyone looking into what Wolbachia-infected Aedes releases are doing to our food chain and specifically vertebrates?

Are we going to foolishly cling to Hertig's 1936 results on mice and chicken embryos? Or, are we going to acknowledge and devote resources to testing vertebrates (including humans) for the presence of Wolbachia?

Because here are facts that are being willfully ignored:

The direct effect of Wolbachia can either impede or promote the pathogen's replication and survival (Zug and Hammerstein, 2015). Examples of neutral or pro-pathogenic effect of Wolbachia include: Brugia pahangi (Dutton and Sinkins, 2005); Japanese encephalitis (JE) Virus (Tsai et al., 2006); Drosophila C Virus (Osborne et al., 2009); and Plasmodium gallinaceum (Baton et al., 2013).

Wolbachia Enhances West Nile Virus (WNV) Infection in the Mosquito Culex tarsalis: http://journals.plos.org/plosntds/article?id=10.1371/journal.pntd.0002965

Zika Virus in Salivary Glands of Five Different Species of Wild-Caught Mosquitoes from Mexico: http://www.biorxiv.org/content/early/2017/06/19/151951

Re: Sexual Transmission of Zika

There is commonly held belief that Zika is rarely a sexually-transmitted disease. However, "up to 47 percent of ZIKV cases in Barranquilla, with 95 percent confidence, may have been due to sexual contact alone." Source: http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S1755436516300330

North Atlantic right whales are highly promiscuous (as are some humans).

Over 28,000 cases of Zika were reported in Puerto Rico as of Oct. 26th, 2016. The waters surrounding many islands in the Caribbean are obviously teeming with Zika-infected Aedes and Culex mosquitoes, eggs, and larvae. Eventually, Cal fin and krill will be nibbling away at them. 

So, the major food source of North Atlantic right whales will also be exposed to the Zika virus and Wolbachia — both are maternally inherited.

There are multiple ways these whales could be infected with Wolbachia and/or Zika.

Bottom line: These whales (and many marine mammals, shorebirds, and humans) are being exposed to inordinate amounts of Wolbachia (a reproductive parasite).

When I asked Dr. Daoust about Zika, WNV, SLEV, and Wolbachia, he replied weakly that these whales were in various states of decomposition, downplayed the likelihood of a mosquito biting them and so these were not even considered; nor tested for.

comment_message_cleaned: Why doesn't EC place a radar somewhere around the southernmost area of NS? Whenever I check the radar of an incoming system, whether it's a hurricane or a Nor'easter, you see it limited within a radius centered around Halifax. Often I hear meteorologists on tv remind viewers, while presenting a radar loop, that precipitation is actually in the neighborhood but we can't see it because it doesn't reach far enough out to pick it up. So, wouldn't having another radar set up further south complement the other, and help with the forecast? I know we use imagery from the US but even their radar doesn't extend out to fill that void.
text_filtered: EC place radar somewhere around southernmost area NS Whenever check radar incoming system whether hurricane easter see limited within radius centered around Halifax Often hear meteorologists tv remind viewers presenting radar loop precipitation actually neighborhood see reach far enough pick another radar set south complement help forecast know use imagery US even radar extend fill void

text_original: Why doesn't EC place a radar somewhere around the southernmost area of NS? Whenever I check the radar of an incoming system, whether it's a hurricane or a Nor'easter, you see it limited within a radius centered around Halifax. Often I hear meteorologists on tv remind viewers, while presenting a radar loop, that precipitation is actually in the neighborhood but we can't see it because it doesn't reach far enough out to pick it up. So, wouldn't having another radar set up further south complement the other, and help with the forecast? I know we use imagery from the US but even their radar doesn't extend out to fill that void.

comment_message_cleaned: " It has been shown that nighttime temperatures recorded by many weather stations have been artificially raised by the eulsion of radiant heat collected and stored during the daytime by concrete and brick structures such as houses, buildings, roads, and also cars. Since land area of cities and large towns containing these weather stations only make up a very small fraction of the total land area, this influence on global average temperature data is significant. Since the daytime and nighttime temperatures are combined to form an average, these artificially-raised nighttime temperatures skew the average data. When one only looks at daytime temperatures only from larger urban areas, the “drastic global warming” is no longer visible. (This can also be seen when looking at nearby rural area weather station data, which is more indicative of the true climate of that area)."

text_original: " It has been shown that nighttime temperatures recorded by many weather stations have been artificially raised by the expulsion of radiant heat collected and stored during the daytime by concrete and brick structures such as houses, buildings, roads, and also cars. Since land area of cities and large towns containing these weather stations only make up a very small fraction of the total land area, this influence on global average temperature data is significant. Since the daytime and nighttime temperatures are combined to form an average, these artificially-raised nighttime temperatures skew the average data. When one only looks at daytime temperatures only from larger urban areas, the “drastic global warming” is no longer visible. (This can also be seen when looking at nearby rural area weather station data, which is more indicative of the true climate of that area)."

comment_message_cleaned: How do you distinguish a false emotional response from a true one? I think it is hard to keep emotions out if this issue, maybe more so in our case as we live in central BC and have seen the pine beetle almost completely wipe out our pine trees, the fir trees now under attack from their beetle, and the worst fire season on record this summer, all of which can be attributed in large part to the overall warmer climate. I think this issue has a great deal to do with our relatively extravagent (on average) lifestyles: if one believes human activity is a major contributor in global warming, ocean acidification/dead zones, air/water/land pollution, greatly accelerated species extinction, etc, etc, then one cannot help but feel somewhat responsible.

text_original:
How do you distinguish a false emotional response from a true one? I think it is hard to keep emotions out if this issue, maybe more so in our case as we live in central BC and have seen the pine beetle almost completely wipe out our pine trees, the fir trees now under attack from their beetle, and the worst fire season on record this summer, all of which can be attributed in large part to the overall warmer climate.
I think this issue has a great deal to do with our relatively extravagent (on average) lifestyles: if one believes human activity is a major contributor in global warming, ocean acidification/dead zones, air/water/land pollution, greatly accelerated species extinction, etc, etc, then one cannot help but feel somewhat responsible.

comment_message_cleaned: You keep emotions out of it by looking at the data and trying to make sense of it. You have to find the facts and rely on them even when your emotions tell you otherwise. I'm on Vancouver Island ... we've had the smoke from this summer's fires. The interesting bit is that temperatures are on average cooler this summer ... even as BC was warmer and drier as normal. Greenland had the coldest ever July temperature recorded in the north hemisphere. Yeah ... if you believe human activity is responsible for global warming and the catastrophic events ... hurricanes fires floods etc ... you might think its our fault ... except your belief is not substantiated by facts. There are not now more or worse hurricanes floods fires than have occurred in the recent past. You need only look at the data. The only difference is we've been fighting forest fires for over years instead of letting it burn as nature intended ... now you get a fire and there is no way to put it out because of the fuel that has accumulated ... so in this way humans are responsible for changing the natural fire cycle for one that is worse ... but thats not the same as saying its due to anthropogenic climate change when there is no evidence to support it.

text_original: You keep emotions out of it by looking at the data and trying to make sense of it. You have to find the facts and rely on them even when your emotions tell you otherwise. I'm on Vancouver Island ... we've had the smoke from this summer's fires. The interesting bit is that temperatures are on average cooler this summer ... even as BC was warmer and drier as normal. Greenland had the coldest ever July temperature recorded in the north hemisphere. Yeah ... if you believe human activity is responsible for global warming and the catastrophic events ... hurricanes fires floods etc ... you might think its our fault ... except your belief is not substantiated by facts. There are not now more or worse hurricanes floods fires than have occurred in the recent past. You need only look at the data. The only difference is we've been fighting forest fires for over 50 years instead of letting it burn as nature intended ... now you get a fire and there is no way to put it out because of the fuel that has accumulated ... so in this way humans are responsible for changing the natural fire cycle for one that is worse ... but thats not the same as saying its due to anthropogenic climate change when there is no evidence to support it.

comment_message_cleaned: I don't deny that atmospheric CO2 is rising. I'm skeptical that it's having the effect that some people claim it has. It is a very weak green house gas and because of the narrow band that it's effective in it rapidly becomes less of a GHG at higher concentrations. There are other probably more important factors at work.

comment_message_cleaned: The earth has been warming up since the last ice age ended. With only a few hundred years of actual weather being tracked it can be hard to determine what the real impacts will be. But we can only watch and determine the effects so that we can forecast major weather activity and strive to warn the public far enough ahead to protect life. Weather can change very quickly anywhere and we must be vigilant to our surroundings. When it comes to the game of weather mother nature can not be beat but we can learn to work with her in protecting our selves and property.

Weather can change very quickly anywhere and we must be vigilant to our surroundings. When it comes to the game of weather mother nature can not be beat but we can learn to work with her in protecting our selves and property.

When Culex mosquitoes naturally acquire Wolbachia (and there are multiple ways this can happen), they were better vectors of West Nile virus and malaria. Study sources: My PSA (just published) connects the dots (with studies):
text_filtered: Regarding deaths North Atlantic right whales Whales infected encephalitis viruses Study sources believe Wolbachia infected Aedes eggs larvae waters southeastern areas around northeastern Brazil wherever right whales winter problem Culex mosquitoes naturally acquire Wolbachia multiple ways happen better vectors West Nile virus malaria Study sources PSA published connects dots studies
text_stemmed: [u'regard', u'death', u'north', u'atlant', u'right', u'whale', u'whale', u'infect', u'enceph', u'virus', u'studi', u'sourc', u'believ', u'wolbachia', u'infect', u'aed', u'egg', u'larva', u'water', u'southeastern', u'area', u'around', u'northeastern', u'brazil', u'wherev', u'right', u'whale', u'winter', u'problem', u'culex', u'mosquito', u'natur', u'acquir', u'wolbachia', u'multipl', u'way', u'happen', u'better', u'vector', u'west', u'nile', u'virus', u'malaria', u'studi', u'sourc', u'psa', u'publish', u'connect', u'dot', u'studi']
text_original:
Regarding the deaths of North Atlantic right whales: Whales can be infected by encephalitis viruses. Study sources: 
https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/15566723 
https://wwwnc.cdc.gov/eid/article/17/8/10-1979_article

And I believe Wolbachia-infected Aedes eggs and larvae in the waters of southeastern U.S. and areas around northeastern Brazil (and wherever right whales "winter" are the problem). When Culex mosquitoes naturally acquire Wolbachia (and there are multiple ways this can happen), they were better vectors of West Nile virus and malaria. 
Study sources: http://journals.plos.org/plosntds/article?id=10.1371/journal.pntd.0002965
http://rspb.royalsocietypublishing.org/content/royprsb/281/1779/20132837.full.pdf

My PSA (just published) connects the dots (with studies): https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=JrSuDXGKaNY&t

comment_message_cleaned: Dear Honorable Minister Catherine McKenna, carbon (CO2) is the building block of life and is as important for life as oxygen. Application of the term "carbon pollution" is incorrect and takes away attention from the poisonous substances in the environment. The use of long established term "Green House Gases (GHG)" will be factually and scientifically correct and an honest way of communicating the great carbon mitigation efforts with Canadians. Regards

text_original: Dear Honorable Minister Catherine McKenna, carbon (CO2) is the building block of life and is as important for life as oxygen. comment_message_cleaned: Here are my top ten ideas: . Introduce tougher fines for people who litter . Put into place stronger laws and regulations to stop businesses from polluting our environment -land, water and air (I'm not talking about a carbon tax here) . Eand existing protected lands, conservation areas, parks and waterways at the municipal, provincial and federal levels . Create NEW protected lands, conservation areas, parks & waterways . Encourage volunteers to get more involved with protecting our environment. Ie. cleaning up parks and planting trees . Help make the public more aware of ways to be environmentally friendly on a daily basis. Ie. commuting, recycling . Offer even greater incentives (rebates/tax credits) for electric car purchases and initiatives to make homes more energy efficient / energy independent (solar panels, geothermal, wind mills) . Pursue clean, renewable energy sources in both the public & private sector (hydro power, solar, wind, geothermal) . Introduce tougher laws that protect all species of animals in Canada . Stronger laws protecting against logging / clear cutting of trees A lot of these ideas are budget friendly or are investments that will save people, businesses and government money in the long term from energy savings!
text_filtered: top ten ideas Introduce tougher fines people litter Put place stronger laws regulations stop businesses polluting environment land water air talking carbon tax Eand existing protected lands conservation areas parks waterways municipal provincial federal levels Create NEW protected lands conservation areas parks waterways Encourage volunteers get involved protecting environment Ie cleaning parks planting trees Help make public aware ways environmentally friendly daily basis Ie commuting recycling Offer even greater incentives rebates tax credits electric car purchases initiatives make homes energy efficient energy independent solar panels geothermal wind mills Pursue clean renewable energy sources public private sector hydro power solar wind geothermal Introduce tougher laws protect species animals Canada Stronger laws protecting logging clear cutting trees lot ideas budget friendly investments save people businesses government money long term energy savings
text_stemmed: [u'top', u'ten', u'idea', u'introduc', u'tougher', u'fine', u'peopl', u'litter', u'put', u'place', u'stronger', u'law', u'regul', u'stop', u'busi', u'pollut', u'environ', u'land', u'water', u'air', u'talk', u'carbon', u'tax', u'eand', u'exist', u'protect', u'land', u'conserv', u'area', u'park', u'waterway', u'municip', u'provinci', u'feder', u'level', u'creat', u'new', u'protect', u'land', u'conserv', u'area', u'park', u'waterway', u'encourag', u'volunt', u'get', u'involv', u'protect', u'environ', 'ie', u'clean', u'park', u'plant', u'tree', u'help', u'make', u'public', u'awar', u'way', u'environment', u'friend', u'daili', u'basi', 'ie', u'commut', u'recycl', u'offer', u'even', u'greater', u'incent', u'rebat', u'tax', u'credit', u'electr', u'car', u'purchas', u'initi', u'make', u'home', u'energi', u'effici', u'energi', u'independ', u'solar', u'panel', u'geotherm', u'wind', u'mill', u'pursu', u'clean', u'renew', u'energi', u'sourc', u'public', u'privat', u'sector', u'hydro', u'power', u'solar', u'wind', u'geotherm', u'introduc', u'tougher', u'law', u'protect', u'speci', u'anim', u'canada', u'stronger', u'law', u'protect', u'log', u'clear', u'cut', u'tree', u'lot', u'idea', u'budget', u'friend', u'invest', u'save', u'peopl', u'busi', u'govern', u'money', u'long', u'term', u'energi', u'save']
text_original:
Here are my top ten ideas:  :)

1. Introduce tougher fines for people who litter
2. Put into place stronger laws and regulations to stop businesses from polluting our environment -land, water and air (I'm not talking about a carbon tax here)
3. Expand existing protected lands, conservation areas, parks and waterways at the municipal, provincial and federal levels 
4. Create NEW protected lands, conservation areas, parks & waterways
5. Encourage volunteers to get more involved with protecting our environment. Ie. cleaning up parks and planting trees
6. Help make the public more aware of ways to be environmentally friendly on a daily basis. Ie. commuting, recycling
7. Offer even greater incentives (rebates/tax credits) for electric car purchases and initiatives to make homes more energy efficient / energy independent (solar panels, geothermal, wind mills) 
8. Pursue clean, renewable energy sources in both the public & private sector (hydro power, solar, wind, geothermal)
9. Introduce tougher laws that protect all species of animals in Canada
10. Stronger laws protecting against logging / clear cutting of trees

A lot of these ideas are budget friendly or are investments that will save people, businesses and government money in the long term from energy savings!

comment_message_cleaned: We are wondering if the Government of Canada has solutions to the issue of the emission of greenhouse gases due to shipping and manufacturing imported goods. We have conducted a survey to see if there is a correlation between the amount of time students spend on their phones and how often they shop online. After critically analyzing the data, we have concluded that there is a strong positive correlation between the two. Many pupils spend hours on apps and websites that sell imported goods and shop frequently from them.

text_original: We are wondering if the Government of Canada has solutions to the issue of the emission of greenhouse gases due to shipping and manufacturing imported goods. We have conducted a survey to see if there is a correlation between the amount of time students spend on their phones and how often they shop online. After critically analyzing the data, we have concluded that there is a strong positive correlation between the two. Many pupils spend hours on apps and websites that sell imported goods and shop frequently from them.  #YouthClimateAction #ClimateChange

comment_message_cleaned: Pipelines reduce greenhouse gases and if you want the oil industry to go, you'd better be ready to give up everything from your toothbrush to your car. Not because your car needs oil to function, but because it is made using oil based products from your dashboard to tires, most plastics and all rubber. No winter boots, sports equipment, medical supplies....are oil based. Alternative energy such as wind and solar can be used to heat and light up your home, but can not replace oil in manufacturing of thousands of products we use everyday.

Same goes for the speakers, although that largely reflects hiring/promotion bias. #uncomfortabletruths

Look at the facts Minister. Why are you focusing on coal when the real issue is in our modern diet.

comment_message_cleaned: I'm an alumna of Students On Ice Arctic , and as I said I have been to COP times. I am incredibly grateful to have had those eeriences; in my humble but determined view, this summit is largely ignoring the real issues we are desperately trying to discuss and address -- including Pacific LNG and Kinder Morgan, Energy East, Line , continued violence at the tar sands, Muskrat Falls, and racialized and gender-based violence across the country... The way we address climate change must be justice-based and urgent. I don't see willingness from Canadian government to engage meaningfully, in a public narrative, in this way.

text_original: I'm an alumna of Students On Ice Arctic 2008, and as I said I have been to COP 3 times. I am incredibly grateful to have had those experiences; in my humble but determined view, this summit is largely ignoring the real issues we are desperately trying to discuss and address -- including Pacific LNG and Kinder Morgan, Energy East, Line 9, continued violence at the tar sands, Muskrat Falls, and racialized and gender-based violence across the country... The way we address climate change must be justice-based and urgent. I don't see willingness from Canadian government to engage meaningfully, in a public narrative, in this way.

comment_message_cleaned: When it comes to people making individual changes in their lifestyle it's, for the majority, not viable unless supported by infrastructure. Firstly in the GTA there aren't feasible methods of public transportation to get into the city unless you are commuting right downtown, and a commuter culture is always going to be the reality when property in Toronto is so eensive, because of this many people drive with no real alternative. Secondly, on a daily basis I see so many people with disposable water bottles. Why not encourage people to use reusable water bottles by placing water bottle refilling stations in public areas like train stations, and subway stops. Or even going further and having those locations be "water bottle free" where businesses and vending machines located within these areas don't sell bottled water and instead there is access to refill stations. Lastly is diet, everybody has been saying it, but as far as I know the Canadian government invests in cattle farming. These are just obstacles that I see that could be improved to help people change their lifestyles, are there areas that the Canadian government is working to help every person have a lifestyle with less of an environmental impact?

comment_message_cleaned: Minister, youth met with you at COP22. Did you hear our stories? Youth want climate action and that means no pipelines and no fossil fuel infrastructure. Treaty Alliance Against Tar Sands signed by nations refuses consent, people mobilizing across our country refuse consent, and youth do not consent. The world needs us to stop being a drug pusher of oil to market. We signed an international commitment and now it's time to honour it.

text_original: Minister, 15 youth met with you at COP22. Did you hear our stories? Youth want climate action and that means no pipelines and no fossil fuel infrastructure. Treaty Alliance Against Tar Sands signed by 89 nations refuses consent, people mobilizing across our country refuse consent, and youth do not consent. The world needs us to stop being a drug pusher of oil to market. We signed an international commitment and now it's time to honour it. #KeepItInTheGround #stopKM

comment_message_cleaned: Clayton, what would you recommend to increase First Nations engagement with panels such as this? I've been discussing it with my roommates, and we were discussing the possibilities of ) sending direct invites to First Nations youth who have demonstrated an interest in the subject, and ) providing funding to offset the travel costs faced by on-reserve youth for whom transport poses a problem. What do you think of these ideas, and what other solutions would you propose?

text_original: Clayton, what would you recommend to increase First Nations engagement with panels such as this? I've been discussing it with my roommates, and we were discussing the possibilities of 1) sending direct invites to First Nations youth who have demonstrated an interest in the subject, and 2) providing funding to offset the travel costs faced by on-reserve youth for whom transport poses a problem. What do you think of these ideas, and what other solutions would you propose?

comment_message_cleaned: Translate for :19:30 Parks Canada has a student employment opportunity called Northern Engagement and Outreach, in which we design activities we can use to talk about Northern Parks and promote the Arctic and Northern Canada. Kim and I where based in Montreal, and designed a Greenscreen activity that allows you to adopt a glacier in one of the parks that you promise to protect, so you take a picture with it. comment_message_cleaned: Yep, knew that years ago. They are affected by colder temps though so a bacteria we would use in The Gulf? would not work so well here in BC. They are amazing little creatures, can lay dormant for a very long time until they sense oil then they increase enentially and consume the oil with sulpher as their waste and when the oil is consumed they decrease,also enentially until a few of them go dormant until the next time. When you walk on a black muddy beach and smell that sulpher smell? that is these orginisms waste that you are stirring up and that means they are present and waiting.

It appears that the proposed Liberal carbon tax is just another tax grab to move money from the public to the government.

Could you please explain why the federal government wants to tax us for CO2 emissions when our nation - the second largest in land mass in the world and one of the least populated countries in the world, 230th out of 241 countries, 3.4 persons per square km. contains 9% of the world's forests?
In 2014 Canada produced 732 million tonnes of co2 emissions, and our forest absorbed 2220.8 million tonnes - why do we need a carbon tax?
This does not include the hydro electricity we export to the USA for which we should also get credits.

comment_message_cleaned: I will be going to Algonquin Park. The last time we went my husband and his buddy rescued a loon that had a fishing lure stuck in its beak. It also had a hook stuck in its wing so it couldn't eat or fly. They caught in a fishing net after an hour of chasing it in our canoe. They caught it, carefully pulled the lure and hook out, and set it free. My husband said they are so much bigger up close and they bite lol. He forgot his camera which I don't think he will forget to keep it on him again. But he said it came out of the water flapped it's wings and started fishing. The best time he's ever had in Algonquin. We love nature.

text_original:
Canada is already bankrupt.
2 trillion+ in debt.
The debt is sold on the us and London stock exchange.
Foreign bidders win the opportunity to extraCT as much oil n gas n minerals as they can then pawn their shares back on the market.
They bring in their own temperate foreign workers and avoid hiring locals.

The public funds and union pensions and band council trust funds get invested through she'll holdings in the Isle of man and Panama and then reinvested through companies like Petronas and the Malaysian government.
Those entities  establish offices in other countries like China. 
Then negotiate deals with those regions to provide resources that they speculate they can extract from Canada. 
Then they "negotiate" agreements with the provincial and federal government of Canada for resource extraction and return the embezzled money to the politicians and lawyers who in turn "invest" that money to the private contractors and holdings that were involved in originally structuring the fraudulent scheme in the first place.

Then we blame the Chinese when in actuality it's our own so called government to blame and those corporate offices may be located in China however it is not the Chinese who are at fault.

And then we blame the less fortunate in our society for living off tax dollars and meanwhile our hard working middle class is taxed upwards of 50% from their paycheck to pay off the Queens mortgage.

Yet and still bc has a soaring debt getting close to a trillion dollars and the Federal government claims a debt beyond 2 trillion.

Meanwhile tiny little Switzerland boasts revenue surplus in the area of several trillion dollars annually through tourism revenue.

The west coast has the potential tial to generate even greater profits through a properly managed tourism industry that is eco friendly and at the same time would create a massive and permanent job creation and labour market.

Without the need for taxation. 

All this could be obtained by the mainstream population under the jurisdiction of unceded tribal nations and then everyone would have lots of money, lots of time to spend with loved ones, opportunity to travel and to enjoy life, free fish and free food.

Incorporate free energy technologies with our knowledge of natural medicines and nutritional food values and reduce unhealthy circumstances.

Countries like China and India are manufacturing building supplies that can build a skyscraper in less than 30 days and Taiwan has built skyscrapers designed to grow food already.

Meanwhile the BRICs are developing a system that allows for travel without the need for passports and a more viable banking system than the imf.

But....what do I know? 
I'm just a tree hugging hippy with a bunch of useless ideas.

Get back to work everyone.

Even though modern technology can potentially see a world that only requires 10% of the population to work while everyone else celebrates their freedom to do whatever, we should categorize such a concept under banners that we have been taught are bad.
Freedom is not good remember, unless you are killing somebody.

P.s.
Canada is not even a country nor an ethnicity.  It's a white supremacist corporation owned by the British crown in London which is owned by northern Europeans who pose as Germans.  Follow the clues.  Norway bankrolled Rome when Rome designed the famous railways system and communication network that was in turn handed over to hitlers regime to conduct the Holocaust of Europe. 
When Hitler figured that out he turned on the northern Europe coalition responsible. 
When he did the Norway royals fled to Ontario where they stayed in a little town that is now called "little norway" because of this snafu.
After the secret allies of fascism in North America and Europe publicly revolted against the Hitler regime in response, suddenly we are told that he is bad even though we were helping him to become what he was before he bit the hands that fed him.

When Hitler fell many of his highest ranking officers relocated to Canada where they assumed advisory positions to the crown and continued their global subjection racket with a primary focus on first nations people.
Same formula.  Same purpose.

Anyways...back to work.  We got a crown debt to pay.  And don't give any money to beggars because it's their own fault they are compromised right?

The vast majority of homeless people came from foster care.  The vast majority of inmates at correctional facilities came from foster care.

Is it the foster care administration who are directly responsible for manufacturing a crime rate and poverty market?

The vast majority of foster children are first nations therefore can it be safe to suggest we are still witnessing genocide right in plain view?

Nevermind.  Nothing we can do about it.
It's not like Iceland demonstrated it can be done without violence...or did they?

comment_message_cleaned: A good read......... Randy Pompetti is the author of the note below. He lives in Hanna, Alberta, Canada My fellow Canadians, you are buying into a lie regarding our energy industry and the global environment. We are a mere million people, just % of this planet’s billion population. Our country covers roughly million square kilometres of which probably % is realistically uninhabitable (elaining why over % of our population live in urban centres within kms of the U.S. border) We endure temperature extremes ranging from C or colder to C or warmer. Out of necessity we need to heat our homes for + months the year. We face major transportation challenges simply because of the geography of our country. Yet, through all this we are responsible for less than % of the pollution generated globally. We ARE NOT the problem! If every one of us here in Canada chose to sacrifice ourselves for the betterment of mother earth and self-terminated, the positive effect on the global environment would be…..drum roll please……zero! The global effect would actually be negative because we are one of the most ethical, environmentally responsible producers of energy in the world! If we were out of the picture the U.S. would be mining our oil sands before our corpses had even started giving off methane gas. They would then proceed to build the biggest pipeline imaginable, from Fort Mac to Texas. Don’t believe me? Let’s look at some facts. The U.S. has no problem with pipelines; U.S. pipelines that is. They actually have over ‘million’ kilometres of liquid petroleum and natural gas pipelines already. There’s also the kilometre, cm (48 inch) line running from Prudhoe Bay to the Valdez Marine Terminal (yes, big bad oil tankers). You are aware, aren’t you, of the Trans Alaskan pipeline running directly through the pristine heart of that beautiful state? As of , ‘BILLION’ Barrels of oil had been transported through this U.S. pipeline and terminal. The U.S. also has no problem drilling for oil in the Atlantic ocean, the Pacific ocean, the Arctic ocean or the Gulf of Mexico yet they have the audacity to condemn Canada for mining our oil sands in northern Alberta and Saskatchewan? The opposition to our Canadian energy development is a well-organized attempt to keep our Canadian oil land locked so that we are forced to sell to the U.S. and to the U.S. only and then at a very discounted price. The U.S. is attempting and succeeding in preventing us from marketing our own natural resources globally to the highest bidder. U.S. foundations (HP, Tides – THE ROCKEFELLERS – et al) are funding the opposition to our oil sands and contrary to popular belief it has absolutely nothing to do with threats to the environment. If they really were that concerned about our planet why are they not protesting the real polluters, the real threats to our environment? China, the world’s worst polluter (besides having a tragic human rights record)? No protests. Why isn’t David Suzuki over in Beijing chastising Jinping? What about the other major polluters? Russia? The U.S. themselves? India? I can understand a Canadian that is benefiting financially, who is receiving grants to oppose or protest or hamstring our own resource development. What I can’t understand is the rest of my fellow Canadians buying into their bovine excrement. In the oil sands, our very own Canadian oil sands, we have the rd largest proven crude oil reserve in the world, behind only Saudi Arabia and Venezuela – again, both with ‘stellar’ human and women’s rights track records. EVERY person in Canada, and EVERY province and territory in Canada has benefited tremendously, whether directly, indirectly or both from our oil sands development. Over the next years the oil sands has the potential to generate over $1.5 TRILLION in federal and provincial taxes and royalties. Of course Quebec will need their share – but, oh yeah, they don’t want a pipeline either! There is the potential for well over ,000 direct and indirect jobs. So here’s the deal my fellow Canadians. I fear our Canadian ‘goose that lays the golden egg’ is suffering the death by a thousand cuts. Alas, it may already be too late. Maybe it’s already on life support. If you share the views of the Gore’s, the Suzuki’s, and the Obama’s of the world, that our Canadian energy producers and those that work in this industry are bad and evil and a scourge on the Earth, a blight on Canada’s reputation in the global community then fine, stick your fork into the goose as well but please do not whine and complain or years down the road when the wait time for your hip replacement is -5 years because our health care system is underfunded and there’s a severe shortage of doctors and nurses in the system. Meanwhile, the Suzukis and their ilk will be flying down to the Mayo clinic in a big bad fossil fuel burning jet for their medical needs. Don’t whine and complain when your grandchild’s class has a :1 student to teacher ratio because our education system is underfunded and the government coffers are bare. Of course the Suzuki grandchildren will be in private schools so no problem there. Don’t whine and complain when your city’s infrastructure is decaying and falling apart and there’s no money to repair it. Instead of whining and complaining, make sure you look into the mirror and realize you believed a lie that has cost this incredible country and our future generations an amazing opportunity to prosper and succeed globally.

text_original:
A good read.........

Randy Pompetti is the author of the note below. He lives in Hanna, Alberta, Canada

My fellow Canadians, you are buying into a lie regarding our energy industry and the global environment. We are a mere 35 million people, just 0.5% of this planet’s 7.3 billion population. Our country covers roughly 10 million square kilometres of which probably 90% is realistically uninhabitable (explaining why over 80% of our population live in urban centres within 200 kms of the U.S. border)

We endure temperature extremes ranging from -40C or colder to 35C or warmer. Out of necessity we need to heat our homes for 6+ months the year. We face major transportation challenges simply because of the geography of our country. Yet, through all this we are responsible for less than 0.5% of the pollution generated globally.

We ARE NOT the problem! If every one of us here in Canada chose to sacrifice ourselves for the betterment of mother earth and self-terminated, the positive effect on the global environment would be…..drum roll please……zero!

The global effect would actually be negative because we are one of the most ethical, environmentally responsible producers of energy in the world! If we were out of the picture the U.S. would be mining our oil sands before our corpses had even started giving off methane gas. They would then proceed to build the biggest pipeline imaginable, from Fort Mac to Texas.

Don’t believe me? Let’s look at some facts. The U.S. has no problem with pipelines; U.S. pipelines that is. They actually have over 3.2 ‘million’ kilometres of liquid petroleum and natural gas pipelines already. There’s also the 1300 kilometre, 122cm (48 inch) line running from Prudhoe Bay to the Valdez Marine Terminal (yes, big bad oil tankers). You are aware, aren’t you, of the Trans Alaskan pipeline running directly through the pristine heart of that beautiful state?

As of 2010, 16 ‘BILLION’ Barrels of oil had been transported through this U.S. pipeline and terminal. The U.S. also has no problem drilling for oil in the Atlantic ocean, the Pacific ocean, the Arctic ocean or the Gulf of Mexico yet they have the audacity to condemn Canada for mining our oil sands in northern Alberta and Saskatchewan?

The opposition to our Canadian energy development is a well-organized attempt to keep our Canadian oil land locked so that we are forced to sell to the U.S. and to the U.S. only and then at a very discounted price. The U.S. is attempting and succeeding in preventing us from marketing our own natural resources globally to the highest bidder. U.S. foundations (HP, Tides – THE ROCKEFELLERS – et al) are funding the opposition to our oil sands and contrary to popular belief it has absolutely nothing to do with threats to the environment.

If they really were that concerned about our planet why are they not protesting the real polluters, the real threats to our environment? China, the world’s worst polluter (besides having a tragic human rights record)? No protests.

Why isn’t David Suzuki over in Beijing chastising Jinping? What about the other major polluters? Russia? The U.S. themselves? India? I can understand a Canadian that is benefiting financially, who is receiving grants to oppose or protest or hamstring our own resource development. What I can’t understand is the rest of my fellow Canadians buying into their bovine excrement.

In the oil sands, our very own Canadian oil sands, we have the 3rd largest proven crude oil reserve in the world, behind only Saudi Arabia and Venezuela – again, both with ‘stellar’ human and women’s rights track records. EVERY person in Canada, and EVERY province and territory in Canada has benefited tremendously, whether directly, indirectly or both from our oil sands development.

Over the next 25 years the oil sands has the potential to generate over $1.5 TRILLION in federal and provincial taxes and royalties. Of course Quebec will need their share – but, oh yeah, they don’t want a pipeline either! There is the potential for well over 500,000 direct and indirect jobs.

So here’s the deal my fellow Canadians. I fear our Canadian ‘goose that lays the golden egg’ is suffering the death by a thousand cuts. Alas, it may already be too late. Maybe it’s already on life support. If you share the views of the Gore’s, the Suzuki’s, and the Obama’s of the world, that our Canadian energy producers and those that work in this industry are bad and evil and a scourge on the Earth, a blight on Canada’s reputation in the global community then fine, stick your fork into the goose as well but please do not whine and complain 10 or 15 years down the road when the wait time for your hip replacement is 3-5 years because our health care system is underfunded and there’s a severe shortage of doctors and nurses in the system. Meanwhile, the Suzukis and their ilk will be flying down to the Mayo clinic in a big bad fossil fuel burning jet for their medical needs.

Don’t whine and complain when your grandchild’s class has a 50:1 student to teacher ratio because our education system is underfunded and the government coffers are bare. Of course the Suzuki grandchildren will be in private schools so no problem there. Don’t whine and complain when your city’s infrastructure is decaying and falling apart and there’s no money to repair it. Instead of whining and complaining, make sure you look into the mirror and realize you believed a lie that has cost this incredible country and our future generations an amazing opportunity to prosper and succeed globally.

comment_message_cleaned: Good Evening. I've been reviewing the "Planning for a Sustainable Future" website. One of the locations it recommended to discuss suggestions for the development of an Environmental Action Plan was your facebook page. I've been researching this issues for over decades. During that time I have found thousands of different solutions to this problem from brilliant people all over the world. I respect the complex nature of this issues as it related to the economy and the various regional concerns. One thing is very clear and that is the burning of greenhouse gas emitting fuels must end. It is my hope those industries effected can be repurposed to reduce the negative impacts of the transition. Having said that there is one very obvious solution that meets and exceeds all of your stated requirements. "Seawater" it is the most abundant greenhouse gas free fuel on the planet. It is readily available for use. It is extremely clean & safe to use. All of our existing combustion engine technology is capable of burning it with small modifications. Most important, many other options exist which do not require burning it at all to power all our energy requirements. One benefit to burning seawater is the byproduct. Freshwater H20. I would purpose that Canada should start manufacturing "seawater powered turbine generators" for electricity production. Secondary benefit is freshwater production / conversion. Third benefit would be to help reduce the impacts of sea level rising by converting the seawater into freshwater. Forth benefit : Existing combustion engines can be used to Hydrogen as a replacement fuel similar to propane. Finally, This is not rocket science. People are already doing with worldwide. The real economic benefit here for Canada is doing it better than everyone else. We can do this. This technology would be outstanding for North communities as they can utilize both seawater, fresh water & snow to power their homes days per year. This would help Canada better utilizing its land and claim that territory by occupying it more effectively. Below is a number of videos outlining said technology and some additional more advanced electron based uses of seawater. I hope this has been helpful in any small way & would be happy to provide additional links or reference material if required. Regards, Marc Santos

u'water', u'snow', u'power', u'home', u'day', u'per', u'year', u'would', u'help', u'canada', u'better', u'util', u'land', u'claim', u'territori', u'occupi', u'effect', u'number', u'video', u'outlin', u'said', u'technolog', u'addit', u'advanc', u'electron', u'base', u'use', u'seawat', u'hope', u'help', u'small', u'way', u'would', u'happi', u'provid', u'addit', u'link', u'refer', u'materi', u'requir', u'regard', u'marc', u'santo']
text_original:
Good Evening. I've been reviewing the "Planning for a Sustainable Future" website. 

One of the locations it recommended to discuss suggestions for the development of an Environmental Action Plan was your facebook page. 

I've been researching this issues for over 3 decades. During that time I have found thousands of different solutions to this problem from brilliant people all over the world.

I respect the complex nature of this issues as it related to the economy and the various regional concerns. One thing is very clear and that is the burning of greenhouse gas emitting fuels must end.

It is my hope those industries effected can be repurposed to reduce the negative impacts of the transition.

Having said that there is one very obvious solution that meets and exceeds all of your stated requirements.

"Seawater" it is the most abundant greenhouse gas free fuel on the planet. It is readily available for use. It is extremely clean & safe to use.

All of our existing combustion engine technology is capable of burning it with small modifications. 

Most important, many other options exist which do not require burning it at all to power all our energy requirements.

One benefit to burning seawater is the byproduct. Freshwater H20.

I would purpose that Canada should start manufacturing "seawater powered turbine generators" for electricity production. 

Secondary benefit is freshwater production / conversion.

Third benefit would be to help reduce the impacts of sea level rising by converting the seawater into freshwater.

Forth benefit : Existing combustion engines can be used to Hydrogen as a replacement fuel similar to propane.

Finally, This is not rocket science. People are already doing with worldwide. 

The real economic benefit here for Canada is doing it better than everyone else.  We can do this.

This technology would be outstanding for North communities as they can utilize both seawater, fresh water & snow to power their homes 365 days per year.

This would help Canada better utilizing its land and claim that territory by occupying it more effectively.

Below is a number of videos outlining said technology and some additional more advanced electron based uses of seawater.

I hope this has been helpful in any small way & would be happy to provide additional links or reference material if required.

Regards,

Marc Santos

The challenge is who can make money at using Carbon for a product
Can we - Universities Research labs, Industry Research Labs, independent Research Labs , sell this Cleaning knowledge on these Cleaning Tools to other countries, other industries and other Researchers 
Only when people can make money at green technology will the drive to improve our environment be a priority.

You may be assured that your comments and suggestions have been duly noted and are appreciated. Once again, thank you for taking the time to write. J.P. Vachon Manager/Gestionnaire Executive Correspondence Services for the Prime Minister's Office Services de la correspondance de la haute direction pour le Cabinet du Premier ministre From : <jamesk.klassen.com> Received : Apr :30:43 AM >>> You can Help the World meet the Paris Agreement, Reduce smog worldwide, Increase Trade employment, Give First Nations an opportunity to succeed, and cover the eenses created with Federal Revenues with ONE activity! We have a global problem we all need to address and Canada can play an important role in solving this problem. The world population grows, is using th century energy sources (coal) to generate electricity to fuel their desire for a North American lifestyle. Starting now, we as Canadians can provide a cleaner burning alternative: Natural Gas. This fuel in its newer form will help us all transition to a st century of entirely renewable energy sources. We all share this beautiful planet and we need to work together on practical solutions to this global problem. If we keep fighting over the solutions we will not move forward. And speaking of working together - here in BC we have government representatives, industry, northern community residents and First Nations Bands engaging in meeting the issues! If there is an area that Canadians shine at its our excellence in - its ethical industry operating in compliance - demonstrating environmental stewardship excellence. Please clear the way for this green solution we will stick with the science but we can't let excessive bureaucracy and gerrymandering tie us up any more. Counting on you, James Klassen Canada - True North Strong and Free.

text_original:
I sent you a letter already - The PMs got a copy but here it is -

On behalf of the Right Honourable Justin Trudeau, I would like to
acknowledge receipt of your correspondence. 

Thank you for writing. The Prime Minister welcomes the views of
Canadians on the issues that are important to them, whether supportive
or critical. You may be assured that your comments and suggestions have
been duly noted and are appreciated.

Once again, thank you for taking the time to write. 

J.P. Vachon 
Manager/Gestionnaire 
Executive Correspondence Services 
for the Prime Minister's Office 
Services de la correspondance 
de la haute direction 
pour le Cabinet du Premier ministre 

 From :    <jamesk.klassen@gmail.com>   Received :    Apr 26 2016
12:30:43 AM   >>> 

You can Help the World meet the Paris Agreement, Reduce smog worldwide,
Increase Trade employment, Give First Nations an opportunity to succeed,
and cover the expenses created with Federal Revenues with ONE activity!

We have a global problem we all need to address and Canada can play an
important role in solving this problem. 

The world  population grows, is using 19th century energy sources (coal)
to generate electricity to fuel their desire for a North American
lifestyle.

Starting now, we as Canadians can provide a cleaner burning alternative:
Natural Gas. This fuel  in its newer form will help us all transition to
a 21st century of entirely renewable energy sources.

We all share this beautiful planet and we need to work together on
practical solutions to this global problem. If we keep fighting over the
solutions we will not move forward.

And speaking of working together - here in BC we have government
representatives, industry, northern community residents and First
Nations Bands engaging in meeting the issues!

If there is an area that Canadians shine at its our excellence in - its
ethical industry operating in compliance - demonstrating environmental
stewardship excellence. 

One of these solutions is clean burning Canadian Natural Gas which can
now be exported Globally in the Liquefying process and is known as LNG.

Did you know the US (via Alaska) has been exporting Liquefied Natural
Gas to Japan for 50 years. 

But of course you have the data it's been on the Federal Government
Website for years : Please see Policy Horizons Canada The Role of
Infrastructure in Integrating Asia's Regions at
http://www.horizons.gc.ca/eng/content/role-infrastructure-integrating-asias-regions written by Jean-Phillip Veilleux.

It has all kinds of handy sources for helping make good decisions
including pipeline distribution maps in Asia. 

Perhaps it's time for Canada to join the world in supplying this cleaner
fuel? We have an abundance of it and the taxes generated will help us
all. It will tackle deficits, It will cover programs. LNG It will
generate opportunity for First Nations in employment and opportunity, It
will put people back to work, it will help the middle class. It will
improve the debt to GDP ratio. It will reduce world emissions. It sound
like an opportunity to meet so many of the Liberal Campaign promises!

Help us teach and reach the world with our economically viable, safely
transportable, readily available, thermally efficient "super fuel". It's
a mouthful but if you say it makes you smile!

Please clear the way for this green solution we will stick with the
science but we can't let excessive bureaucracy and gerrymandering tie us
up any more.

Counting on you, 

James Klassen

Canada - True North Strong and Free.

Make the first nations an equal and very important capital partner in this endeavour and establish an aboriginal federal ministry and provincial and territorial aboriginal cabinet with controlling political interest in all aspects of land use and environmental policy.  They knew what they were doing forever and still do.  Terraform Canada with hemp and then strategically position permanent natural gas and industrial hemp crops both east and wet and let the entities share transportion.  No energy east or west just Canadian nationalized natural gas just like Norway.  Reinstate the bank of Canada through production profits to further dismantle the deficit and reinstate all protective laws for all Canadian lands that Harper eliminated. That is a better plan than a carbon tax,  something for fuel,  land reclamation, industrial application,  food,  job creation,  first nations relations in short a pragmatic solution.

comment_message_cleaned: Ban them, like Ontario did - when will the Federal government lead, versus just consult and sort-of follow? As long as we obsessively increase global travel, with few safeguards in place to stop the flow of invasive species (simple boot/shoe-cleaning stations entering and exiting airports and ferry terminals, for example, should have been implemented universally, decades ago...), then it will continue, enentially. Same is true if we continue to ignore the facts, and countless bodies of research, on the damage being done by global trade agreements, particularly free-trade agreements, that both the Liberals and Conservatives are addicted to. This is despite no proven long-term benefit for Canada financially, in jobs, and especially in environmental health and protection. Canadian small business is shrinking annually; Canadian companies are being bought, mostly by American giants, at an ever-increasing rate; our family farms are vanishing, either due to lack of affordability, less local demand, or being swallowed up by corporate mega-farms; and affordability for living, in general, continues it's fall off the cliff - acknowledged even by the CMHC... These posts are nice, but until a real response and action based on hard science, Canadian eerience, and indigenous knowledge is made, they are just a delay tactic.

text_original: Minister Catherine McKenna, why not convert Canada's energy infrastructure for all purposes (electricity, transport, heating/cooling, industry, agriculture/forestry/fishing) to clean, renewable energy? Science led by Dr. Mark Z. Jacobson at Stanford University shows this is technologically and economically feasible. We need to do this on a large scale. By electrifying everything and using a combination of onshore and offshore wind, residential and commercial solar, utility-scale solar, geothermal, wave, tidal, and existing hydroelectric, we'd reduce all-sector end-use power demand by ~43% and create more jobs than lost. His team recommends 80% conversion in all-sectors by 2030 and 100% by 2050. His peer-reviewed roadmaps offer policy measures to enable this transition. To learn more, please visit: www.100.org or for the detailed science: http://go100.me/50StateTargets #CANClimateAction

text_original:
When will details of carbon tax mechanics be released?

The Oil Climate Index helps shed light on what this could mean for Canada's oil sector. If extraction projects are in fact subject to the tax, a barrel of Hibernia oil (NL) (which produces 487kg CO2 eq/barrel) would cost $24.35 more in 2022. A barrel of Athabasca DC SCO (736kg CO2 eq/barrel) would see a price hike of $36.80/barrel. 
http://oci.carnegieendowment.org/#total-emissions

If this tax applies to extraction, it will render any plans for expansion of the tar sands much less profitable in any long term financial analysis. This could effectively kill any projects without the government having to stop them on regulatory grounds. Same logic could apply to fugitive emissions stemming from Lelu methane export terminal. 

Will loopholes for extraction be allowed? You can bet CAPP is lobbying furiously for them.
