comment_message_cleaned: Open pit oil sands extraction actually only accounts for about % of the workable area of the oil sands. The rest is done by SAGD or other means of less excavation scope with 'drilling'. Only a fraction of the oil sands will require the mining technique, yet all the eco group concerns make it sound like the entire area will be mined, when in fact the MAJORITY of the oil sands will be drilled with little disturbance! We need to educate much louder and factually than the misinformation presented by the 'anti' crowd. We just need Federal and Provincial Governments with vision, that encourage and reward industry to be environmental, efficient, economical and successfully provides an atmosphere that nurtures jobs, innovation and optimization! We just need Governments that are proud of our ability to effectively supply the World, yes Governments that are Proud, not embarrassed! We need Governments that base policies FOR Canadians, based of Reality, rather than wasting Canada's opportunity by following False Agendas! Let's get the pipeline access to new Markets now, while we have the Manpower and unemployment! We have % of a world resource used by EVERYONE for EVERYTHING, EVERYWHERE. Why wait for $100/bbl to get Market Access, the time is now! It is odd and rather ironic that the only things delaying the success of Canada and Canadians, are the very Politicians elected to represent us?

comment_message_cleaned: Some engineering facts that are relevant towards the decisions and opinions that need to be made.... ) The world energy consumption continues to grow, and a large majority of that is with fossil fuels. ) Canada has amongst the largest reserves of these, and this business has been no.1 in terms of GDP, govt revenues, and employment in this nation. Nothing comes close until maybe now. ) Coal produces about lbs/MMBTU of GHG (on the avg), and Natural Gas produces lbs/MMBTU. The switching of fuel from all coal to gas in the world would reduce GHG emissions by nearly half (some Gtn's). Gas burning has much less Nox's and SO2's and technology for CCS (Carbon capture and sequestration) is greatly facilitated. Research allocation to this topic would be well spent if it was done. ) Large scale wind and solar projects, subsidized by govt's the world over are....challenged. Both technically in terms of delivering adequate amounts of power when needed with adequate uptime, and economically (people and industry are paying very much more for their power). The efforts have so far raised the cost of living for the poor, at the benefit of the company's being subsidized to deliver wind and solar.. ) Allowing individuals to make their own choices for 'greening' their way of life is much more likely to have more success due to the detail that is involved in deciding priorities, and what best serves the interest of that individual. Indeed society is made up of individuals, is it not? ) Canada contributes % of the worlds GHG, not accounting for any CO2 absorption from our vast forests and lakes, and land. Does everyone consider it sensible we curtail our competetiveness in the world O and G market? Do you really believe we can make a difference by performing self-flagellation of our oil and gas industry? ) If one were to review the details of the well barrier standards that are in place today in the Danish sector of the North Sea, you will observe they are carbon copy of the Canadian ones. I know this because I put them there. Canada has second to none engineering and operating standards, and these are partly (at least) in place in every place where I have been employed. ) Oil production involves the production of methane when gas comes out of solution. Many Opec countries do not bother with this off-gas and just either burn or vent it. text_original:
Some engineering facts that are relevant towards the decisions and opinions that need to be made....

1) The world energy consumption continues to grow, and a large majority of that is with fossil fuels.

2) Canada has amongst the largest reserves of these, and this business has been no.1 in terms of GDP,  govt revenues, and employment in this nation. Nothing comes close until maybe now.

3) Coal produces about 215 lbs/MMBTU of GHG (on the avg), and Natural Gas produces 117 lbs/MMBTU. The switching of fuel from all coal to gas in the world would reduce GHG emissions by nearly half (some 6 Gtn's). Gas burning has much less Nox's and SO2's and technology for CCS (Carbon capture and sequestration) is greatly facilitated. Research allocation to this topic would be well spent if it was done.

4) Large scale wind and solar projects, subsidized by govt's the world over are....challenged. Both technically in terms of delivering adequate amounts of power when needed with adequate uptime, and economically (people and industry are paying very much more for their power). The efforts have so far raised the cost of living for the poor, at the benefit of the company's being subsidized to deliver wind and solar..

5) Allowing individuals to make their own choices for 'greening' their way of life is much more likely to have more success due to the detail that is involved in deciding priorities, and what best serves the interest of that individual. Indeed society is made up of individuals, is it not?

6) Canada contributes 1.7% of the worlds GHG, not accounting for any CO2 absorption from our vast forests and lakes, and land. Does everyone consider it sensible we curtail our competetiveness in the world O and G market? Do you really believe we can make a difference by performing self-flagellation of our oil and gas industry?

7) If one were to review the details of the well barrier standards that are in place today in the Danish sector of the North Sea, you will observe they are carbon copy of the Canadian ones. I know this because I put them there. Canada has second to none engineering and operating standards, and these are partly (at least) in place in every place where I have been employed.

8) Oil production involves the production of methane when gas comes out of solution. Many Opec countries do not bother with this off-gas and just either burn or vent it. Likewise produced water in many Opec countries is treated very minimally before being disposed of back into the environment. Canada and its Canadian engineers and operators do their work with an astronomically higher standard of ethics than what I have seen and witnessed in my experience working abroad. Stop demonizing the quality engineering of your own compatriots. This is very wrong!

9) Unlike wind and solar, Canadian oil and gas industry IS NOT subsidized. Unlegislated tax not being collected cannot be categorized as a subsidy.

comment_message_cleaned: You've touched on it all - Carbon Price (Fee & Dividend), World Carbon Price (Go Stefan Dion), encouragement to sustainable energy via market incentives, new targets. But it seems so slow from here; where's the urgency and audacity that your young audience feels? And where's the progress on reducing subsidies to fossil fuels? Sure, Alberta is hurting, but it still doesn't make sense to continue them while simultaneously proposing carbon pricing. On subsidies, it's so murky, everything from the IMF's estimates, to declarations from government that they are already reduced or gone, nobody even knows what subsidies are today, so claims of reducing them aren't comparable to a base line. Emissions targets are equally muddy - % of some date by some date. The only one that people really understand is zero by , committed to in Paris.This translates to % per year from today for years. So track progress against a simple target annually and report on it honestly even if we miss. The Paris target is probably not good enough to achieve degrees, and degrees is probably not good enough to avoid catastrophe, but I can dream that if we start with that and it turns out not to be as hard as some fear then we can go faster. I know you don't want to be the minister with no power, but you can't compromise with physics. I really do believe that you and your government mean what they say and are only compromising so that you can have the power to do good, but I need something more than smiles and promises. I need to see the Real Change that the campaign promised.

comment_message_cleaned: Renewables are not the answer, at least not at this point in time. Check out wind power in Germany, Australia or even Ontario, it is not viable yet. Too intermittent and dilute, impossible to control the power grid with them connected. Same problem with solar. Also both have a larger environmental footprint by the time they're installed including attainment of raw materials, processing, manufacture, and maintenance (clearing ice from the blades with helicopters and for solar the low amount of sun during winter) Also both only last years or less in our climate. Natural gas fired power has a yr. life. That's beside the fact that current wind turbine design is poor and each one kills thousands of predatory birds and bats every year. Wind and solar cost much more than they ever return in value. If wind and solar are ever to be viable it would be on a micro rather than macro scale. Each new building could have both but battery technology must be improved. Geothermal a real possibility but large enough installations haven't been tested yet. Natural gas is still the best, least eensive, plentiful, very low emissions and very controllable. It can be supplemented with CCS. BUT CO2 emissions are not really that much of a concern. Anthropogenic CO2 only makes up 2% of the GHGs in the atmosphere and Canada as a whole contributes only % percent of that. More than % of GHGs is naturally occurring and we have no control over them. Also Canada's vast Boreal forests currently are a carbon sink that absorb more CO2 than we emit. Ruining our economy for this insignificant amount of CO2 in these circumstances is a fool's errand. Governments and the UN have another agenda and a larger political purpose for pushing the climate change fears. The current CO2 concentration is around ppm and is barely above the ppm required to support most plant life. The concentration has been as high as ppm in earth's past and coincidentally that is the same concentration that many greenhouses maintain for optimum plant growth. Controlling climate change is arrogance, just like saying we can control earthquakes! Even so reducing our CO2 emissions is probably not a bad thing although probably not worth the costs but could be a consideration in the design of buildings and all fossil fuel burning equipment in the future.

text_original:
Renewables are not the answer,  at least not at this point in time. Check out wind power in Germany,  Australia or even Ontario, it is not viable yet.  Too intermittent and dilute,  impossible to control the power grid with them connected.  Same problem with solar. Also both have a larger environmental footprint by the time they're installed including attainment of raw materials,  processing,  manufacture, and maintenance (clearing ice from the blades with helicopters and for solar the low amount of sun during winter) Also both only last 20 years or less in our climate. Natural gas fired power has a 50 yr. life. That's beside the fact that current wind turbine design is poor and each one kills thousands of predatory birds and bats every year. 
Wind and solar cost much more than they ever return in value. If wind and solar are ever to be viable it would be on a micro rather than macro scale. Each new building could have both but battery technology must be improved.
Geothermal a real possibility but large enough installations haven't been tested yet. 
Natural gas is still the best,  least expensive,  plentiful, very low emissions and very controllable. It can be supplemented with CCS. 
BUT CO2 emissions are not really that much of a concern.  Anthropogenic CO2 only makes up 0.12% of the GHGs in the atmosphere and Canada as a whole contributes only 1.7% percent of that. More than 99.6% of GHGs is naturally occurring and we have no control over them. Also Canada's vast Boreal forests currently are a carbon sink that absorb more CO2 than we emit. 
Ruining our economy for this insignificant amount of CO2 in these circumstances is a fool's errand. Governments and the UN have another agenda and a larger political purpose for pushing the climate change fears.  
The current  CO2 concentration is around 400 ppm and is barely above the 200 ppm required to support most plant life. The concentration has been as high as 1200 ppm in earth's past and coincidentally that is the same concentration that many greenhouses maintain for optimum plant growth. 
Controlling climate change is arrogance,  just like saying we can control earthquakes! Even so reducing our CO2 emissions is probably not a bad thing although probably not worth the costs but could be a consideration in the design of buildings and all fossil fuel burning equipment in the future.

comment_message_cleaned: PIPELINES - TIDEWATER ACCESS For the past + years every pipeline project has been met with fierce organized resistance. The Socialists have done everything possible to ensure that they would not obtain approval. Three things have made this fairly easy for them to accomplish. First is they paint the proponents as Big Bad Oil & Gas Corporations that are only concerned about making obscene profits. This allows them to paint themselves as the protectors of everyday normal people who somehow need their interventionist protection. And it diminishes the reality of thousands of normal hardworking people who would benefit from all the opportunities that an eanded market access would provide. Second is they fund and incite Indigenous communities to join them in opposing the "rape and destruction" of their traditional lands. This is often accompanied by an all out effort to portray all the ongoing problems within some remote communities as the fault of prior industry misdeeds. Rather than openly and honestly looking at the many failures of the Socialist Entitlement eeriments which lead Indigenous People away from self sufficiency into a downward spiral of dependence. The worst part of utilizing communities in this manner is it creates difficult to resolve adversarial positions from years of protests and blockades. And it never addresses the root cause of distrust, namely that such communities simply never get an opportunity to work in a mutually beneficial partnership with industry. Third is the way in which the Socialists portray themselves as the only protectors of wildlife and habitat. They organize mass kayak blockades never realizing the hypocrisy of flying thousands of people to jump in petroleum derived plastic kayaks while paddling thru waters rife with the raw sewage discharge of one of their "enlightened" enclave cities. They glorify a living off the land lifestyle while conveniently ignoring the fact that killing of animals for fur and sustenance is our history. And clearing of land to build our homes, raise our crops and yes, build our villages as part of our rightful place on earth. So how do we as ordinary citizens counter these three ingrained socialist pipeline resistance strategies? It really is quite simple. Rather than have a big corporation as the pipeline proponent, form a citizen owned (NOT GOVERNMENT! ) private company to own, propose, develop, build and operate the pipeline project. With ownership limited to citizens from the territories involved and no big money only shareholders. Establish it with tens of thousands of residents within the proposed pipeline route being holders of shares from a $100 to at most $10,000. This makes it a small-c capitalist project that people can relate to as family, friends and neighbors. Not a faceless corporation only looking to the bottom line. Next up is to ensure that the Indigenous People along the route are also individual shareholders who stand to benefit alongside all the other owners. With open access to all the opportunities that might accrue within their traditional land areas. Working alongside another man or woman is the best way to learn that you have so much more in common with them than not. Desire for a better life for your respective families being the most common bond shared by all cultures. And a shared pride in building something together becomes a generational bond that transcends many past perceptions. The final requirement is to exhibit the utmost respect for the environment, biodiversity and wildlife at every stage of a proposal. Point out the fact that even the "green" wind and solar projects contain risks for wildlife that have to be mitigated. And then follow through, don't take shortcuts simply to reduce costs, work with the best practices that have been proven to reduce adverse environmental impacts. Better is always possible, pursue it! A citizen owned project as described above would not need nor should it seek ANY government subsidy or involvement. The regulator and approval bodies would find it EXTREMELY difficult to turn down any appropriately developed proposals. How could they say no to such a CITIZEN initiative? Doing so would lead to total rejection at the next election. I have spoken with citizens and Indigenous groups across several possible routes to Pacific tidewater access. They are just as supportive as many of us here in Alberta to get something moving. The -3% foreign backed Canadian Socialists have worn out their welcome as people everywhere awaken to the reality of failed economies that resistance to responsible developments delivers. At this point routes from Alberta thru the Northwest Territories, Yukon, Alaska and lately even British Columbia are supported by real people throughout. We can sit still and wait for the Rest Of Canada to figure out that they really do need our money. Or we can unite and push forward with projects with our own Social License, not dependent upon their sanctimonious approvals. If you're interested in staying apprised of such a citizen initiative, just email me. And ask your family and friends to do the same. Rachel's NDP government isn't interested in anything but wind and solar. In two days Justin formally signs the COP21 agreement which includes the LEAP Manifesto objectives! Rachel and her NDP cronies have already agreed to everything LEAP asks for, read the agreements for yourself. China, India and Southeast Asia are eanding their Petroleum appetite by over Million barrels per day over the next years. Let's make sure that our children, grandchildren and great grandchildren are shipping our refined products where it's wanted! BTW, one of the first investments the Citizen's Initiative could pursue is the game changer Carbon Capture technology that's a reality today. Our synthetic crude oil could become the lowest carbon footprint resource worldwide. That's what happens when someone puts an obstacle in front of Albertans. We turn it upside down and create another Alberta Advantage! As this technology advances we will also see Coal return as the low emissions low cost leader. Albertans will be traveling worldwide to oversee the installation of this made in Alberta technology. of ! George Clark AlbertansFirst.ca

text_original:
PIPELINES - TIDEWATER ACCESS

For the past 30+ years every pipeline project has been met with fierce organized resistance. The Socialists have done everything possible to ensure that they would not obtain approval. Three things have made this fairly easy for them to accomplish.

First is they paint the proponents as Big Bad Oil & Gas Corporations that are only concerned about making obscene profits. This allows them to  paint themselves as the protectors of everyday normal people who somehow need their interventionist protection. And it diminishes the reality of thousands of normal hardworking people who would benefit from all the opportunities that an expanded market access would provide. 

Second is they fund and incite Indigenous communities to join them in opposing the "rape and destruction" of their traditional lands. This is often accompanied by an all out effort to portray all the ongoing problems within some remote communities as the fault of prior industry misdeeds. Rather than openly and honestly looking at the many failures of the Socialist Entitlement experiments which lead Indigenous People away from self sufficiency into a downward spiral of dependence. The worst part of utilizing communities in this manner is it creates difficult to resolve adversarial positions from years of protests and blockades. And it never addresses the root cause of distrust, namely that such communities simply never get an opportunity to work in a mutually beneficial partnership with industry.

Third is the way in which the Socialists portray themselves as the only protectors of wildlife and habitat. They organize mass kayak blockades never realizing the hypocrisy of flying thousands of people to jump in petroleum derived plastic kayaks while paddling thru waters rife with the raw sewage discharge of one of their "enlightened" enclave cities. They glorify a  living off the land lifestyle while conveniently ignoring the fact that killing of animals for fur and sustenance is our history.  And clearing of land to build our homes, raise our crops and yes, build our villages as part of our rightful place on earth.

So how do we as ordinary citizens counter these three ingrained socialist pipeline resistance strategies? It really is quite simple.

Rather than have a big corporation as the pipeline proponent, form a citizen owned (NOT GOVERNMENT! ) private company to own, propose, develop, build and operate the pipeline project. With ownership limited to citizens from the territories involved and no big money only shareholders. Establish it with tens of thousands of residents within the proposed pipeline route being holders of shares from a $100 to at most $10,000. This makes it a small-c capitalist project that people can relate to as family, friends and neighbors. Not a faceless corporation only looking to the bottom line.

Next up is to ensure that the Indigenous People along the route are also individual shareholders who stand to benefit alongside all the other owners. With open access to all the opportunities that might accrue within their traditional land areas. Working alongside another man or woman is the best way to learn that you have so much more in common with them than not. Desire for a better life for your respective families being the most common bond shared by all cultures. And a shared pride in building something together becomes a generational bond that transcends many past perceptions.

The final requirement is to exhibit the utmost respect for the environment, biodiversity and wildlife at every stage of a proposal. Point out the fact that even the "green" wind and solar projects contain risks for wildlife that have to be mitigated. And then follow through, don't take shortcuts simply to reduce costs, work with the best practices that have been proven to reduce adverse environmental impacts. Better is always possible, pursue it!

A citizen owned project as described above would not need nor should it seek ANY government subsidy or involvement. The regulator and approval bodies would find it EXTREMELY difficult to turn down any appropriately developed proposals. How could they say no to such a CITIZEN initiative? Doing so would lead to total rejection at the next election.

I have spoken with citizens and Indigenous groups across several possible routes to Pacific tidewater access. They are just as supportive as many of us here in Alberta to get something moving. The 2-3% foreign backed Canadian Socialists have worn out their welcome as people everywhere awaken to the reality of failed economies that resistance to responsible developments delivers.  At this point routes from Alberta thru the Northwest Territories, Yukon, Alaska and lately even British Columbia are supported by real people throughout.

We can sit still and wait for the Rest Of Canada to figure out that they really do need our money. Or we can unite and push forward with projects with our own Social License, not dependent upon their sanctimonious approvals. If you're interested in staying apprised of such a citizen initiative, just email me. And ask your family and friends to do the same. Rachel's NDP government isn't interested in anything but wind and solar. In two days Justin formally signs the COP21 agreement which includes the LEAP Manifesto objectives! Rachel and her NDP cronies have already agreed to everything LEAP asks for, read the agreements for yourself. 

China, India and Southeast Asia are expanding their Petroleum appetite by over 20 Million barrels per day over the next 25 years. Let's make sure that our children, grandchildren and great grandchildren are shipping our refined products where it's wanted!

BTW, one of the first investments the Citizen's Initiative could pursue is the game changer Carbon Capture technology that's a  reality today. Our synthetic crude oil could become the lowest carbon footprint resource worldwide. That's what happens when someone puts an obstacle in front of Albertans. We turn it upside down and create another Alberta Advantage! As this technology advances we will also see Coal return as the low emissions low cost leader. Albertans will be traveling worldwide to oversee the installation of this made in Alberta technology. 😉

💪 of 💖! 
George Clark 
AlbertansFirst@shaw.ca

comment_message_cleaned: I am pleased to see that the federal government is hosting a public session on climate change. It is in Ottawa so I can't attend. do you have any plans to have similar events across the country so you can have a real consultation. since I can't attend I would like to share some of my opinions on the subject. . We need to educate ourselves on the issue.During the past regime we were fed so much disinformation. It is still happening. There are lawsuits starting against oil companies for their organized disinformation campaigns. Perhaps we should participate or do something to stop the flow of bad information. .We need to stop building more infrastructure for fossil fuels. Why? Canada is a high cost producer and as such we need to run not walk away from this industry as fast as we can just from a business point of view. To get ourselves to zero carbon by we need to reduce our fossil fuel consumption by % compounded annually or % in absolute terms. This is doable but difficult. to get it done requires a very good plan and no going back to old ways. .We need to set up our tax structure so that living and doing business in the core of a city is rewarded. We cannot build an energy efficient society if we keep subsidizing the flight ot the suburbs. For example a building in the city core should get a tax credit,near the core should be tax neutral and in the suburbs should have a surtax to pay for the cost of power lines ,water lines,roads ,snow removal ,police ,lights and all the services that cost more as you go further out. .Many towns and cities have sources of waste heat that are not being used. In my little city of Edmundston there is a pulp and paper mill that gives off enough waste heat to the water and air to heat all the buildings in the area and to heat all the hot water in the area. We could stop burning wood and oil and save a lot of electricity. .Canada needs a national light pollution law. Lighting uses % of all electricity and is growing at % to % per year. The lighting industry tries to get us to believe that all of this light is helping our safety and security. The science is starting to show that it is hurting us and other organisms on the earth. .One of the answers to employment provided by energy sector is to put people to work cleaning up the mess of abandoned oil wells,oil tanks and coal mines. Many of these people are tradespersons who could also go to work building a new clean energy infrastructure. .We need to get our investment dollars out of fossil fuels. The Canada pension plan invests the money of all Canadians. As such it should be directed by the government to support our polices and get our money out of fossil fuels. There should be clear ,clean non fossil fuel options for people investing in RESP and RRSP. . Canada's foreign aid should be going to help poor countries like Dominican Republic and Haiti move from generating electricity using diesel generators to wind and solar power. . I notice that your government has budgeted billion to help First Nations. This is only a fraction of what they need.One part of the isue with remote communities is that they mostly get electricity and heat from fossil fuels. encouraging them to go renewable would help their dollars to go further and might provide other opportunities for them. .Farming uses a lot of fossil fuels. Do we have a strategy for our agricultural sector to become less fossil fuel dependent? Efficiency? Carbon sequestration in soils? Removing the rural power grid as farms become larger and rural power grid becomes too eensive to maintain for such a small population. . What is our strategy on transportation? Cars? Trains for people and freight? Truck transport? Ships? Airlines?

text_original:
I am pleased to see that the federal government is hosting a public session on climate change. It is in Ottawa so I can't attend. do you have any plans to have similar events across the country so you can have a real consultation. since  I can't attend I would like to share some of my opinions on the subject.

1. We need to educate ourselves on the issue.During the past regime we were fed so much disinformation. It is still happening. There are lawsuits starting against oil companies for their organized disinformation campaigns. Perhaps we should participate or do something to stop the flow of bad information.

2.We need to stop building more infrastructure for fossil fuels. Why? Canada is a high cost producer and as such we need to run not walk away from this industry as fast as we can just from a business point of view. To get ourselves to zero carbon by 2050 we need to reduce our fossil fuel consumption by 6% compounded annually or 3% in absolute terms. This is doable but difficult. to get it done requires a very good plan and no going back to old ways.

3.We need to set up our tax structure so that living and doing business in the core of a city is rewarded. We cannot build an energy efficient society if we keep subsidizing the flight ot the suburbs. For example a building in the city core should get a tax credit,near the core should be tax neutral and in the suburbs should have a surtax to pay for the cost of power lines ,water lines,roads ,snow removal ,police ,lights and all the services that cost more as you go further out.

4.Many towns and cities have sources of waste heat that are not being used. In my little city of Edmundston there is a pulp and paper mill that gives off enough waste heat to the water and air to heat all the buildings in the area and to heat all the hot water in the area. We could stop burning wood and oil and save a lot of electricity.

5.Canada needs a national light pollution law. Lighting uses 25% of all electricity and is growing at 5% to 7% per year. The lighting industry tries to get us to believe that all of this light is helping our safety and security. The science is starting to show that it is hurting us and other organisms on the earth.

6.One of the answers to employment provided by energy sector is to put people to work cleaning up the mess of abandoned oil wells,oil tanks and coal mines. Many of these people are tradespersons who could also go to work building a new clean energy infrastructure.

7.We need to get our investment dollars out of fossil fuels. The Canada pension plan invests the money of all Canadians. As such it should be directed by the government to support our polices and get our money out of fossil fuels. There should be clear ,clean non fossil fuel options for people investing in RESP and RRSP.

8. Canada's foreign aid should be going to help poor countries like Dominican Republic and Haiti move from generating electricity using diesel generators to wind and solar power.

9. I notice that your government has budgeted 3 billion to help First Nations. This is only a fraction of what they need.One part of the isue with remote communities is that they mostly get electricity and heat from fossil fuels. encouraging them to go renewable would help their dollars to go further and might provide other opportunities for them.

10.Farming uses a lot of fossil fuels. Do we have a strategy for our agricultural sector to become less fossil fuel dependent? Efficiency? Carbon sequestration in soils? Removing the rural power grid as farms become larger and rural power grid becomes too expensive to maintain for such a small population.

11. What is our strategy on transportation? Cars? Trains for people and freight? Truck transport? Ships? Airlines?

comment_message_cleaned: I agree that we need electric cars as long as the power used to charge the batteries comes from nuclear energy. There is a serious lack of understanding about energy, even more so about nuclear energy. The industry is maligned and misrepresented by those willing to ignore what science has achieved. These same people who don't take the time to investigate seem willing to sacrifice the well being of the planet over irrational fears of radiation. If the goal of science is to make a better future then we need to look at what is economical and what is healthy for the planet. Coal dominates as the largest energy source not only killing people but much land and ocean life. Nuclear energy is an abundant and clean energy source that outperforms other energy sources per unit of fuel. People like the Dalai Lama, James Hansen and countless scientists who support nuclear energy indicate that acceptance of nuclear is a matter of education. Climate scientists and ecologists who endorse nuclear energy are calling on us to action to prevent climate change. Many pronuclear advocates started as environmentalists and have concluded that to prevent the threat to species extinction and quality of life issues that nuclear energy is the only zero greenhouse gas emissions energy source that can be scaled fast enough and robust enough to be able to replace the abundant energy coal currently provides. The unavailable raw materials needed for wind and solar and the risks of natural gas leakage from gas plants that always get added to compensate for intermittent wind and solar makes the so-called "all of the above" solution impractical. Facts that are misrepresented and ignored.Ontario replaced its coal plants because nuclear energy provides % of Ontario’s electricity and Hydro provides %. Radiation is everywhere and has always been with us. Mammals and all Earth's species have evolved and been equipped to handle radiation naturally. The media coverage that implies Fukushima and Three Mile Island had or could still have fatalities are lies and the exaggerations about Chernobyl's victims with outrageous numbers being perpetuated by the media's awareness that fear sells. New companies like Ontario's Terrestrial Energy are showing us the potential for how new nuclear designs are even safer than already "very-safe" technology and will provide a way to take spent used nuclear fuel as an excellent source of energy itself.

Our natural gas and fracking is not the same as the States, our environmental controls and standards are the highest in the world. Visit the North where natural gas has been drilled for and processed for decades and see how unpolluted and pristine our world is up here. There is not one documented case of contaminated groundwater in BC due to fracking. The environmentalists are playing on your fear.

Visit the North where natural gas has been drilled for and processed for decades and see how unpolluted and pristine our world is up here.  There is not one documented case of contaminated groundwater in BC due to fracking.  The environmentalists are playing on your fear.

Did you find all the answers? 
1) A weather buoy, part of the marine surface weather network. 
2) A satellite receiving station that receives data from weather satellites. 
3) An automatic weather station, part of our land-based weather network. 
4) A weather radar
5) A lightning detector that detects cloud-to-ground lightning. 
6) A weather balloon to which we attach a piece of equipment called a radio-sonde. Weather balloons, launched twice a day, at the same time, worldwide. http://ow.ly/4mHFdP [[SHARE]]

comment_message_cleaned: Try reducing wasteful lighting everywhere. Excessive lighting, whether it be the brightness or the amount of lights everywhere, creates light pollution. Most people think about turning the lights out to save money/reduce fossil fuel consumption but a reduction in wasteful lighting outdoors will lower the haze it creates in the air that washes out the starry skies a night. That's why you can't see many stars in cities and towns. Who doesn't like seeing a star-filled sky with the Milky Way?
text_filtered: Try reducing wasteful lighting everywhere Excessive lighting whether brightness amount lights everywhere creates light pollution people think turning lights save money reduce fossil fuel consumption reduction wasteful lighting outdoors lower haze creates air washes starry skies night see many stars cities towns like seeing star filled sky Milky Way
text_stemmed: [u'tri', u'reduc', u'wast', u'light', u'everywher', u'excess', u'light', u'whether', u'bright', u'amount', u'light', u'everywher', u'creat', u'light', u'pollut', u'peopl', u'think', u'turn', u'light', u'save', u'money', u'reduc', u'fossil', u'fuel', u'consumpt', u'reduct', u'wast', u'light', u'outdoor', u'lower', u'haze', u'creat', u'air', u'wash', u'starri', u'sky', u'night', u'see', u'mani', u'star', u'citi', u'town', u'like', u'see', u'star', u'fill', u'sky', u'milki', u'way']
text_original: Try reducing wasteful lighting everywhere. Excessive lighting, whether it be the brightness or the amount of lights everywhere, creates light pollution. Most people think about turning the lights out to save money/reduce fossil fuel consumption but a reduction in wasteful lighting outdoors will lower the haze it creates in the air that washes out the starry skies a night. That's why you can't see many stars in cities and towns. Who doesn't like seeing a star-filled sky with the Milky Way?

comment_message_cleaned: Are balloons really still necessary?
text_filtered: balloons really still necessary
text_original: Are balloons really still necessary?

comment_message_cleaned: Yes
text_filtered: Yes
text_original: Yes

comment_message_cleaned: Yes, they really are! It's how we get profiles of temperature and dewpoint vertically through the atmosphere. This information is very important to weather forecasting as it provides some of the information the computer models use to forecast the weather. The more launch sites we have, the better information is available which leads to better forecasts. In fact, all such sites around the world launch their balloons within a few minutes of each other, twice a day. The data is provided to the World Meteorological Organization and shared among many countries. If I recall correctly I believe there are sites in Canada.
text_filtered: Yes really get profiles temperature dewpoint vertically atmosphere information important weather forecasting provides information computer models use forecast weather launch sites better information available leads better forecasts fact sites around world launch balloons within minutes twice day data provided World Meteorological Organization shared among many countries recall correctly believe sites Canada
text_stemmed: [u'yes', u'realli', u'get', u'profil', u'temperatur', u'dewpoint', u'vertic', u'atmospher', u'inform', u'import', u'weather', u'forecast', u'provid', u'inform', u'comput', u'model', u'use', u'forecast', u'weather', u'launch', u'site', u'better', u'inform', u'avail', u'lead', u'better', u'forecast', u'fact', u'site', u'around', u'world', u'launch', u'balloon', u'within', u'minut', u'twice', u'day', u'data', u'provid', u'world', u'meteorolog', u'organ', u'share', u'among', u'mani', u'countri', u'recal', u'correct', u'believ', u'site', u'canada']
text_original: Yes, they really are! It's how we get profiles of temperature and dewpoint vertically through the atmosphere. This information is very important to weather forecasting as it provides some of the information the computer models use to forecast the weather. The more launch sites we have, the better information is available which leads to better forecasts. In fact, all such sites around the world launch their balloons within a few minutes of each other, twice a day. The data is provided to the World Meteorological Organization and shared among many countries. If I recall correctly I believe there are 31 sites in Canada.
